quest.name: Once Forged
objectives: Survey the designated location and defeat any enemies that appear.

dialogue.name: ALPHINAUD
dialogue.text: 'Tis strange to hear Father spoken of in such a way...but I suppose he would find your view of me no less odd.

dialogue.name: ALISAIE
dialogue.text: Much as I'd like to press Theopauldin for more revealing tidbits, we should be getting back to our tasks.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: In the event that our─and I quote─“promised heap of adamantite falls right out of the bloody sky and into my lap,” Master Kokkol wishes to be ready to put the proverbial hammer to anvil at a moment's notice.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: To fabricate these parts, however, he needs the flames in Kokkol's Forge to burn hotter. He sent me to increase the amount of aether being funneled to his furnaces.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: The flow of fire-aspected aether in Labyrinthos is regulated by an elemental reactor south of here─to which I have borrowed the key.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: The adjustment will require two people to carry out safely...but I can explain the process when we arrive.

dialogue.name: ALISAIE
dialogue.text: This is where we part, then.

dialogue.name: ALISAIE
dialogue.text: We'll see you in Sharlayan Hamlet once the adamantite arrives, if not before.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: This way, then!

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: The reactor is housed within this facility.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: I'll be the one to go inside and adjust the fire aether output.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: When I do, a rather large amount of water-aspected aether will issue from the vent at the top. I expect this to attract at least a few elementals─which we would both rather not be drawn into the reactor itself. Trust me.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Can I ask that you put down any that draw too near? They'll pose you little trouble, I'm sure.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Wait here, if you would!

dialogue.name: POPMESSAGE
dialogue.text: An apa is lured by the siren song of water-aspected aether!

dialogue.name: POPMESSAGE
dialogue.text: Further creatures have been attracted by the font of aether!

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Did everything go smoothly out here?

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: I thought as much. No major complications to speak of inside, either.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: ...And the water aether appears to be venting properly.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: I expect Kokkol will have seen a difference in his forge-flames by the time I return.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Since I have you...there was another matter I thought to discuss with you.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Nothing terribly important─merely something I've been considering.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Part of this, I shared with everyone. Yet you, and only you, have been to Elpis...

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: As we have established, refined adamantite is a product of Allag. Of the empire's twilight years, in fact.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: It was a material which saw much use as part of the Allagans' efforts to extend beyond the bounds of this world─Dalamud, of course, being the most prominent.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Of those who would push further─expand Allag's empire to encompass the heavens and the stars above─perhaps the greatest was its infamous technologist, Amon.

dialogue.name: Q1
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A1
dialogue.text: Amon wanted to travel the sea of stars?

dialogue.name: A1
dialogue.text: Did he remember his life as Hermes?

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: He did. He must have had his own reasons, however, for there is no evidence to suggest that he retained memories of his life as an ancient.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: I believe he had his own reasons. There is no evidence to suggest that he retained memories of his former life.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: He only joined the Ascians once the empire was all but dust, as you know.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: If not his memory, though, what drove him to pursue the idea with such fervor?

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: This may seem far-fetched, but what if souls, like minds, have...a personality, so to speak? A natural disposition towards which they are inclined?

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: We know with relative certainty that it was the gross decadence and inexorable decline of Allag that moved Amon to resurrect Emperor Xande.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: The empire's people spoke lightly of death and destruction, experimenting on those they deemed beneath them to fill the emptiness in their hearts.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: In facilitating Xande's return, Amon provided these languid souls with the means to free themselves from the mire of their own indolence.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: ...Or would have, had not Xande been convinced by his own death that life itself was meaningless.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Amon's desire for his countrymen to conquer the heavens could only be a means to the same end─to instill the people with new purpose.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Like Hermes before him, Amon was appalled by how those around him lived, but could never bring himself to believe that those lives were devoid of meaning.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: And both of them sought that meaning, that hope, in the distant stars.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: ...Such is my theory, anyway.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Ultimately, it is the consequences of their actions which matter. Their motives are of no moment. And yet...

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: To reach those stars on wings of adamantite. To travel to the ends of creation and beyond. The promise of hope everlasting...that much I do understand.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: But enough musing for now. Why don't we see how Kokkol is getting on?

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: I did thoroughly brief Kokkol on refined adamantite's history. I only volunteered to go to the reactor because I was finished and there was little else to do.

dialogue.name: GRAHATIA
dialogue.text: Hopefully that dispels any misapprehensions that I was kicked out for prattling on...

dialogue.name: KOKKOLDANKKOL
dialogue.text: Whew! I can feel those flames a-blazin' from here!

dialogue.name: KOKKOLDANKKOL
dialogue.text: Glad you found someone capable, G'raha, but there's not much left for you lot to do.

dialogue.name: KOKKOLDANKKOL
dialogue.text: 'Less you can conjure up that refined adamantite any faster...?
